title: I got served with sum-100 form for credit card debt that I was not able to pay because my financial hardship; HOW TO RESPOND?
question: I have 30 days to respond and how do I do that what form to use? Do I need to get the lawyer?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Wage garnishment,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes
answers: You might want a free consultation with a bankruptcy attorney. If you have other debt you cannot pay then this lawsuit is probably the beginning of the lawsuits. You will lose the case eventually so you can settle it by making a lump sum payment if you have access to some cash or pay a greater amount in payments but that will depend on what the creditor will accept. You might have to pay court filing fees and hire an attorney to represent you and negotiate a settlement if possible. Again bankruptcy might be the only way to get a fresh start free of unsecured debt. If you make too much money or have too much property you might benefit from Chapter 13. Again, look at the advantages and disadvantages of bankruptcy first not after you start the never ending frustrating and expensive process of defending a bunch of lawsuits.

First, please see on my Avvo profile my legal guide on settling a debt after being served with the lawsuit, so you can save the court's filing fees if you can get it settled. Second, if the company is not reasonable when you try to settle, contact an experienced debt collection defense attorney, so that you do not try to represent yourself and end up with a larger judgment against you.

I explain in my law blog, linked below, reasons why you do not want to represent yourself by filing some papers that you believe that you had prepared properly. It will cost you more money and a judgment can be a nightmare to pay off, if the collection attorney aggressively enforces it through wage garnishment, bank levy, and other procedures.

You can file a General Denial Form PLD-050. See weblink
